Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Interacting with Cyberinfrastructure in the Face of Changing Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will develop a framework to understand the set of sociotechnical relationships that comprise cyberinfrastructure (CI). Cyberinfrastructures are distributed organizations supported by such technologies as supercomputers and high-speed networks. Scientific cyberinfrastructures, or eScience projects, are multiplying rapidly because they can be brought to bear on some of the world's most important problems in energy, the environment, health, and security. The technical challenges of cyberinfrastructure are already so demanding that projects often have little time to engage reflexively on how cyberinfrastructures are used and created in the current state of rapid scientific change in which the necessity of data sharing and multidisciplinary approaches is putting pressure on disciplinary boundaries. While the ability to pool data can enable scientists to answer questions that no single investigator or laboratory could answer individually, large-scale databases also bear the significant burden of supporting scientific sub-domains with different priorities and requirements.

This project will use ethnographic methods, including participant-observation and semi-structured interviews, to investigate: How scientists and engineers decide which cyberinfrastructure resources (e.g. databases and tools) to use and under what circumstances; Under what circumstances do scientists and engineers decide to create their own resources; How are scientists and engineers mixing disciplinary practices within their own laboratories; When do scientists and engineers adopt hybrid identities (e.g. computational biologists and bioinformaticists).

This project will make empirical and conceptual contributions to research in areas such as computer supported cooperative work, science and technology studies, and the study of CI. It will provide a corpus of material describing how local concerns shape the use of CIs and the development and use of alternative local resources. By contributing to a more sophisticated understanding of how eScience is dependent on both technical and social transformation, this research will stimulate and support the development of future eScience research. This project will benefit cyberinfrastructure users and developers, funding bodies and policy makers, by creating a typology of change related to scientific practice, training, and technological change. The education components will give students hands-on involvement in research including developing research instruments, collecting and analyzing data, and writing papers. Diverse students from undergraduate to postdoctoral level, including women and minorities, will emerge with practical skills as well as exposure to theoretical issues related to collaboration and eScience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This longitudinal qualitatative study investigated the evolving practices of twenty-first century data-intensive scientific research to develop better conceptual understandings of this vital work. Through a survey of 350 research leaders at the University of Washington and our subsequent multi-year qualitative investigation of four different scientific groups in four disciplines (climate science, marine geophysics, physics & astronomy, and microbiology) this research produced key insights into the actual practices of modern data-intensive science. These research findings offer an in-depth look at data-intensive scientific practices and illustrate the complexities and creativity of this vital work. Our work helps practicing scientists better reflect on their day-to-day activities while offering more nuance conceptualizations of the reality of scientific work for public consumption.

This project's initial survey characterized the landscape of scientific research at a large US research university during the 2010-2011 timeframe. Our report of these findings surfaced these researchers exposure to software production, concerns about working with increasing quantities of data, and challenges to collaboration. These findings offer insights into the state of computational resources in use during this period of time as well as a look at the data intensiveness of leading University of Washington researchers from many disciplines. 

Our multi-year (2011-2015) study of four groups provided in-depth examinations of day-to-day research practices by studying group members from undergraduates through senior researchers. Examining the lifecycles of research projects this study probed the concept of "data processing work," or the often tedious work to take collected data and transform it into a produce that is ready to be analyzed. Our findings demonstrate that such work is far more than a janitorial task but truly a key opportunity for scientists to assess their data and reflect upon the questions they are asking and how they are doing this research. From selecting subsets of data and cleaning it to transforming it to a different format, data processing work practices are integral elements of scientist's work.

Through this project one field site in physics & astronomy was studied in greater depth. This effort examined how this group of scientists helped design & build (as part of a multinational distributed collaboration) a novel radio telescope array, the infrastructure necessary to make this hardware into a scientific data producing instrument, and most importantly their work to produce a high-precision data analysis software pipeline. This subset of the study's work offers the first nuanced examinations of the production of novel scientific software as a way of creating and improving scientific methods. The findings explore how the practices of these physicists creating software express a particular approach to analyzing petabytes of data and testing software using visualizations that characterize the instrument, software, data, and scientific theory.

Our findings furthermore resulted in a typology of coordinative entities as a way to begin to decompose and better specify, articulate, compare, and trace overlapping and changing forms of organizing found in scientific collaborations. Coordinative entities are prototypical cooperative work arrangements scientists use to successfully do research. The four entities in this typology (Principal Group, Aggregation, Federation, and Facility Organization) characterize different common arrangements and enable scholars studying scientific work to disambiguate different ways of working to collect, process, and analyze data in distributed collaborative contexts. Our typology of coordinative entities is a first step to a larger conceptual framework that will continue to improve our understanding of the complex work of organizing scientific groups and projects. It also complements our work developing the Model of Coordinated Action (MoCA) as a way to characterize collaborative work.

This project's findings offer scientists a better understanding of their own work practices and offer opportunities to reflect on the policies guiding scientific funding and the creation of infrastructures to support this type of work. We add depth to the body of Computer Supported Cooperative Work (CSCW) that has investigated such issues and illustrate the deeply intertwined natured of scientific software, data, and research practices in day-to-day collaborative work.
